title: How to Paint an Old Wooden Chair

steps.headline: Determine whether or not your chair is an antique before painting.
steps.description: You may not have thought about it, but old antique furniture actually loses value when it’s painted or altered. If you don’t mind ruining the value of the antique or know for a fact that there’s nothing special about the chair, feel free to go ahead and paint it. If you aren’t sure whether it’s an antique or not, contact an appraisal service to take a look at your chair and tell you what it’s worth. You can still clean your chair, even if it is an antique piece. Keeping an antique chair clean won’t ruin the value. Just stay away from harsh abrasives and chemicals.

steps.headline: Move your chair outside or put a drop cloth underneath it.
steps.description: Sanding will create a lot sawdust, which will be incredibly difficult to clean up if you work indoors. It will also be incredibly hard to keep paint off of other surfaces indoors. Take your chair outside to avoid dealing with the cleanup process. This will also keep paint fumes from irritating your lungs as you work. If you can’t take the chair outside, at least put a drop cloth underneath it and open the windows in your room. If you don’t have a drop cloth and can’t take your chair outside, you can put garbage bags down under your chair to make cleanup easier.

steps.headline: Sand your chair with 80-100 grit sandpaper to remove the old finish.
steps.description: Get 3-4 sheets of 80-100 grit sandpaper from your local hardware store. Hold the sandpaper in your dominant hand and scrub it across every surface of your chair. Work in a combination of firm back-and-forth strokes and circular strokes to fully remove the varnish or finish from your wood.Tip: You can use an orbital sander if you want a cleaner, more uniform finish. You can rent one from your local hardware store. Use a 80-100 grit sandpaper disc and the lowest setting on your sander to cover the entire surface of the chair. Sanding your chair also removes any stains or dirt from the surface. Wrap the sandpaper around the legs, rails, and spindles and twist it to sand these thinner areas. You can also use a sanding brick instead of a sheet of sandpaper if you’d like. If you use sheets, swap them out after the grit is worn down. It may take 2-3 sheets to fully cover larger chairs.

steps.headline: Switch to 150-grit sandpaper and sand the chair again to lift the grain.
steps.description: Once the surface varnish or finish has been mostly removed, switch to a finer grit to lift the grain on the wood. Use back-and-forth strokes and scrape in the direction of the grain to lift it up. Sand the entire chair so that the surface looks uniform and even. You can also use an orbital sander or sanding brick for the second round of sanding as well.

steps.headline: Vacuum the chair and wipe it down with a damp cloth.
steps.description: Get a vacuum with a hose attachment and turn it on to the highest suction setting. Run the hose across every surface of the chair to suck up most of the sawdust. Then, run a clean cloth or towel under warm water and wring it out. Wipe the chair down with the cloth to pull up any remaining sawdust before letting it air dry for 45-60 minutes. If your hose attachment has a brush adaptor, use that instead. Run the bristles over the wood as you’re vacuuming.

steps.headline: Choose between gray and white primer based on the color you’re painting the chair.
steps.description: Get a can of spray primer from your local hardware or paint store. Choose white if you’re planning on painting your chair a lighter color like white, yellow, or baby blue. Choose gray if you’re going to paint your furniture a darker color like black, gray, or navy blue.Tip: You can use a liquid primer if you’d like, but chairs tend to have lots of curves, small edges, and odd angles that will make using a brush or roller quite difficult. If you’re painting the furniture primary red or blue, it’s up to you on whether you want to use gray or white primer. White will make the colors brighter, while gray will mute the colors a little.

steps.headline: Put on a pair of rubber gloves and dust mask.
steps.description: The fumes from spray paint are only dangerous if you’re in an enclosed room, but they can be quite irritating, even outdoors. However, the fumes from aerosol primers are toxic. Protect your lungs by wearing a dust mask or respirator. Paint will also inevitably get on your index finger when you hold the nozzle down. Keep your hands clean by wearing a pair of rubber or latex gloves. If you absolutely have to work indoors, open the windows, turn fans on, and wear a respirator instead of a dust mask.

steps.headline: Apply your first coat of primer to your chair.
steps.description: Apply your first coat of primer by holding the can 10–12 in (25–30 cm) away from the surface of the chair. Use back-and-forth strokes and work from the top down to cover the entire chair. Spray the chair from every angle to cover each side of the rails, spindles, and legs. Don’t forget to spray under the rails, seat, and top bar of the chair. It’s easy to forget about these parts when you’re using spray primer. You can flip the chair over and paint the underside first if you want to, but you don’t have to if you don’t think it’s necessary. The first coat will look kind of clear. This is because the primer is soaking into the grain. This is a sign that you did a good job sanding, so don’t worry about it. Don’t forget to shake your can before using it.

steps.headline: Wait at least 10 minutes before applying a second coat of primer.
steps.description: Give the chair at least 10 minutes to air dry so that the first coat of primer soaks into the wood. Then, once it’s had time to settle, apply a second coat of primer in the exact same way that you applied the first layer. Hold the can 10–12 in (25–30 cm) away from the surface and use identical strokes to the first layer. When you’re done, wait at least 4 hours for the primer to dry before painting.

steps.headline: Get 3-4 cans of spray paint based on your desired finish.
steps.description: Go to your local hardware store and select a spray paint based on the color and type of finish that you want. While you can technically use any kind of spray paint to paint a wooden chair, look for cans that are designed specifically for furniture or interior design by reading the label carefully. Get a standard matte-finish paint for a sleeker, modern look. Matte paint absorbs light instead of reflecting it, so it’s a good choice if you want a uniform, clean look. Semi-gloss paint is the most common option for furniture. It resists stains moderately well and creates a slight shine when light hits it. Gloss paint is usually reserved for furniture that will get really dirty—like cabinets, doors, and countertops. If you want a ton of shine, go for gloss. The chair may be a little sticky to the touch though.

steps.headline: Turn the chair upside-down and paint the bottom surface of the rails and seat.
steps.description: Either stand the chair up on a tabletop or flip it upside-down on the ground. Hold your can 8–10 in (20–25 cm) away from the surface you’re painting and cover the underside of the seat and bottom of the rails. Paint your legs by working from the top down. This way, any drips on the legs will accumulate on the underside of the seat where you won’t notice them. You don’t actually have to do this if you don’t mind getting down on your knees and you have good control with a can of spray paint. Wait at least 15 minutes before flipping the chair back over.

steps.headline: Turn the chair over and finish the first coat by spraying back and forth.
steps.description: Turn the chair right-side up. Hold the can of spray paint 8–10 inches (20–25 cm) away from the surface of the chair. Start at the top of the chair and work your way down. Spray in horizontal strips and cover each section twice as you work down. Work around the entire chair while spraying to apply paint to the sides, and back of the rails, spindles, and legs. Your first coat should look semi-clear, regardless of the color that you’re using. It will take multiple coats to achieve the color that you want.

steps.headline: Wait 1 hour to give the chair time to air dry.
steps.description: After you’ve applied your first coat, give the paint time to soak into the grain and settle. While spray paint can dry in as little as 5-10 minutes, it’s better if you wait at least 1 hour so that the paint soaking into your wood grain has time to dry. If you want to test the paint to see if it’s dry, try touching the underside of the seat. If it’s dry, it will feel smooth to the touch. If it’s wet, it’s not a big deal since nobody will be able to see it under the seat.

steps.headline: Repeat the painting and drying process until you’ve reached your desired color.
steps.description: After you’ve waited 1 hour, apply a second coat using the same color that you used for the first coat. Paint the underside first and then work from the top to the bottom. Use even, horizontal lines to work around the chair. After you’re done, wait another hour before applying more coats. Paint the chair anywhere from 3-6 times until you’ve reached the color that you want to achieve.Tip: If you have plenty of time, wait an extra hour for each additional coat. This will ensure that no moisture gets trapped in your lower layers of paint.

steps.headline: Seal the chair with acrylic sealer to protect the paint.
steps.description: Get a liquid or aerosol sealer from your local craft or building supply store. If you have liquid sealer, fill a paint tray and use a natural brush to apply it to the chair. Use back-and-forth strokes and spread out any drips with an unloaded brush. If you have a spray sealer, apply it the same exact way that you spray painted your chair. Cover each surface and work around the chair to completely seal it. Wait 1 hour and then seal it again for maximum protection. The sealer will lock the paint into the wood and protect it. In the future, if you need to clean your chair, you’ll be able to wash and wipe your chair without worrying about the paint rubbing off.
